A domino reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives using bovine serum albumin as a catalyst Ling-Yu Li a Qing-Qing Zeng a Ya-Xuan Yang a Hong-Feng Hu b Man Xu a Zhi Guan a ⁎ Yan-Hong He a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Applied Chemistry of Chongqing Municipality, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest University, Chongqing 400715, PR China Key Laboratory of Applied Chemistry of Chongqing Municipality, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest University Chongqing 400715 PR China b School of Life Science, Southwest University, Chongqing 400715, PR China School of Life Science, Southwest University Chongqing 400715 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 23 68254091; fax: +86 23 68254091. Graphical abstract Bovine serum albumin (BSA) was used as a catalyst in the domino Michael/intramolecular cyclization reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives. A domino reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives using bovine serum albumin (BSA) as a catalyst in ethanol was described. The domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reactions of readily available 2-hydroxychalcones with malononitrile gave the desired products in yields of 31–96% under the optimized conditions. As an example of biocatalytic methods, this work not only broadens the BSA-catalyzed chemical transformations, but also could be a potential valuable tool in organic synthesis in view of the economical and sustainable catalyst and simple operation. Keywords Bovine serum albumin Biocatalysis Domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction 2-Amino-4H-chromene derivatives 1 Introduction 2-Amino-4H-chromenes are commonly used in cosmetics, paint manufacturing, manufacturing of biodegradable agro-chemicals, and are also important building blocks of numerous biologically active and natural products (Fig. 1 ) [1,2]. For example, the tumor antagonist HA14-1 (1) and its analogues exhibit binding activity to the surface pocket of cancer-implicated Bcl-2 protein and can induce apoptosis in follicular lymphoma B cells and leukemia HL-60 cells [3,4]. The 2-amino-3-cyano-4H-chromene MX58151 (2) with a 3-bromo-4,5-dimethoxyphenyl substituent at the 4-position was considered as a potential agent with multiple action modes against the breast cancer cell line T47D, the lung cancer cell line H1299 and the colorectal cancer cell line DLD-1, and it might have an advantage for the treatment of the drug-resistant cancers as it retains activity in tumor cells resistant toward current antimitotic agents, taxanes (including Taxol and Taxotere), and Vinca alkaloids [3]. Some methods of synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromenes have already been reported, such as the chemical one pot synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromenes [5–9], methods resulting in good yields [10–13] and quite short reaction times [14–17]. Generally, 2-amino-4H-chromenes are synthesized by multi-component reactions involving in Knoevenagel condensation of salicylic aldehydes with active methylene followed by a intramolecular cyclization step, and have employed organic bases, ionic liquids or organic small molecules as catalysts [10,18,19]. Moreover, harsh conditions were required in some reported synthetic methods such as reflux, microwave or electrolysis [1–3]. More recently, some new routes were reported to synthesize 2-amino-4H-chromenes through the domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reactions from readily available 2-hydroxychalcones with malononitrile, employing a small organic molecule [9-amino-9-deoxyepiquinine in combination with (R)-1,1′-binaphth-2,2′-diylhydrogen phosphate] or a basic salt (NaHCO3) as a catalyst, respectively [20,21]. Considering the importance of 2-amino-4H-chromenes in both biological and chemical fields, the development of environmentally friendly catalysts and mild conditions to realize this important transformation is still desirable. Bovine serum albumin (BSA), mainly present in blood plasma, is a carrier protein with no natural catalytic function. Interestingly, BSA as a catalyst or co-catalyst in organic synthesis has been revealed recently. In 2005, Tellier and co-workers reported that BSA could efficiently catalyze the tandem Kemp elimination/β-elimination reaction [22]. In 2007, Reetz and co-workers described that BSA could promote the Morita–Baylis–Hillman (MBH) reaction of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde with cyclohexenone affording the product with a certain degree of enatioselectivity [23]. In 2011, Gotor and co-workers discovered that BSA had the ability to catalyze the Henry reaction between aromatic aldehydes and 1-nitroalkanes in aqueous medium [24]. Sinha and co-workers put forward a method for the synthesis of (E)-α,β-unsaturated compounds via aldol, Knoevenagel or Knoevenagel-Doebner condensations employing bovine serum albumin-1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide (BSA-[bmim]Br) as a catalyst in 2011 [25]. Also in 2011, Gaggero and co-workers reported BSA-catalyzed stereoselective thio-Michael addition of thiols to chalcones in water [26]. In 2012, Wang and co-workers presented that BSA was able to catalyze a Michael-aldol cascade reaction of dibenzoylmethane with methyl vinyl ketone (MVK), while other 1,3-dicarbonyl compounds studied only gave Michael addition products [27]. In 2013, Sinha and co-workers reported that BSA could trigger multicomponent Biginelli reactions for the synthesis of 3,4-dihydropyrimidin-2-(1H)-ones [28]. Also in 2013, Lin and co-workers described a BSA-catalyzed Gewald reaction for the synthesis of substituted 2-aminothiophenes [29]. It can be seen that BSA has drawn increasing attention for use as an inexpensive and environmentally friendly catalyst in organic transformations. Herein, we report a green domino reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives using BSA as a catalyst in ethanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The bovine serum albumin [Light yellow powder, 99% protein (by agarose gel electrophoresis), pH 6.8] was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Shanghai, China (A1933-5G, Lot#SLBG8239V). Another bovine serum albumin [light yellow crystalline powder; 99.50% protein (by electrophoresis); pH 6.9] used as a comparison was purchased from J&K (Catalog Number: 109636; Lot Number: LK30P27). Unless otherwise noted, all reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. 2.2 Analytical methods Reactions were monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent) with Haiyang GF254 silica gel plates (Qingdao Haiyang chemical industry Co Ltd, Qingdao, China) using UV light and vanillic aldehyde as visualizing agents. Flash column chromatography was performed using 200–300mesh silica gel at increased pressure with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent (The flow rate was approximately 13mL/min). 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker-AM 300 (300MHz) (Bruker BioSpin AG Ltd., Beijing, China) and Bruker-AM 600 (600MHz) (Bruker BioSpin AG Ltd., Beijing, China). Chemical shifts were reported in ppm from TMS with the solvent resonance as the internal standard. Data were reported as follows: chemical shifts (δ) in ppm, coupling constants (J) in Hz, and solvent (CDCl3 or d6-DMSO). HRMS were recorded on a Varian 7.0 T FTICR-MS spectrometer. Melting points were taken on a YuHua X-4 apparatus and were uncorrected. 1H NMR and 13C NMR for all the products and HRMS for unknown compounds are available in the Supporting information. 2.3 General procedure for the synthesis of α,β-unsaturated ketones 1a–o and 4a–c [30] For the preparation of 1a–o: 40% aqueous solution of KOH (1.0mL) was added dropwise to a solution of aromatic methyl ketones (4mmol) and salicylaldehyde (0. 61g, 5mmol) in EtOH (5.0mL) and the reaction was carried out at 60°C (or at r.t. for 1d, 1g, 1i and 1j) for 6–12h. The solution/suspension was poured into cold water and the mixture was neutralized with 2M HCl to a pH 2–3. The resulting precipitate was collected, washed with water and recrystallized from EtOH to give 1a–o. For the preparation of 4a–c: The analogous method was employed using acetone as a reactant and solvent. The 1H- and 13C-NMR spectra of α,β-unsaturated ketones 1a–f, 4a and 4b were identical to those synthesized through previously published procedures [30–34]. The characterization data of α,β-unsaturated ketones 1g–o and 4c are available as the Supporting Information. 2.4 General procedure for the BSA-catalyzed domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives 3a–o and 5a–c Ethanol (0.9mL) and deionized water (0.1mL) were added to a round-bottom flask which was charged with BSA (30mg), α,β-unsaturated ketone (0.3mmol), and malononitrile (0.9mmol). The resultant mixture was stirred at 30°C for the specific reaction time and monitored by TLC (petroleum ether/ethyl acetate of 3:1 was employed as the elution system). The reaction was terminated by filtering the BSA; chloroform was used to wash the filter paper and the residue to assure that the products were dissolved in the filtrate; the filtrate was then washed with water to remove most of the excess malononitrile. The organic phase was dried over anhydrous sodium sulfate, and solvents were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by silica gel flash column chromatography with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to obtain the product 3a–l and 3n–o (Solvent ratios of the eluent mixture are listed in the Supporting information, respectively). For the preparation of 3m and 5a–c: the reaction was terminated by filtering the BSA; hot methanol (for 3m) or ethyl acetate (for 5a–c) was employed to wash the filter paper. The solvents in the filtrate were removed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by silica gel flash column chromatography with petroleum ether/ethyl acetate as eluent to obtain the product (Solvent ratios of the eluent mixture are listed in the Supporting information, respectively). 3 Results and discussion Initially, the reaction of 3-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one (1a) with malononitrile (2) was chosen as a model reaction. In order to verify if the BSA could catalyze the model reaction, some control experiments were performed (Table 1 ). In the absence of BSA, the product was obtained only with the yield of 4% (Table 1, entry 1), indicating that a catalyst was necessary to improve this reaction under the present conditions, and also excluding the possibility of chemical catalysis arisen from the impurity in the reactants and reaction medium. When BSA was used as a catalyst, the model reaction gave the product with a good yield of 70%, indicating that BSA could catalyze the model reaction (Table 1, entry 2). The reaction with BSA, pretreated in water at 100°C for 24h, gave a lower yield of 41%, indicating that high temperature caused a certain degree of denaturation of BSA (Table 1, entry 3). Because copper(II) can bind to BSA via the sulfhydryl group on albumin [35], an experiment employing a Cu2+-denatured BSA catalyst was carried out resulting in a very low yield of 7% (Table 1, entry 4). As guanidine hydrochloride (GdnHCl), a more powerful denaturation agent than urea in some respects, can cause perturbation of the BSA secondary structure [25], an experiment with BSA pretreated with GdnHCl was used to mediate the model reaction; the product was obtained in a yield of 33% (Table 1, entry 5). An experiment using BSA pretreated with sodium dodecyl sulfonate (SDS) gave a decreased yield of 28% (Table 1, entry 6), possibly due to the formation of a BSA–SDS complex [36,37]. Considering the fact that the amino groups of BSA can be modified chemically by acetic anhydride according to Taylor's report [38], BSA pretreated with acetic anhydride was used to catalyze the model reaction. As expected, a low yield of 21% was obtained (Table 1, entry 7). The above control experiments not only confirmed that BSA catalyzed the reaction but clearly demonstrated that the higher catalytic activity was furnished by the native form of the protein. The bovine serum albumin we used in this work was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Shanghai, China [A1933-5G, Lot#SLBG8239V, light yellow powder, 99% protein (by agarose gel electrophoresis), pH 6.8]. To further confirm the catalytic effect of BSA on the domino Michael addition/cyclization reaction, another BSA preparation [Albumin, from bovine serum; light yellow crystalline powder; 99.50% protein (by electrophoresis); pH 6.9; purchased from J&K; Catalog Number: 109636; Lot Number: LK30P27] was used as a comparison. The model reaction with BSA (from Sigma-Aldrich) gave a yield of 87% under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 1, entry 8). Under the same conditions, the BSA (from J&K) gave a yield of 78% (Table 1, entry 9). This comparison experiment confirmed that the experimental results are reproducible, not depending on the suppliers and the lot of the albumin used. As reaction medium is one of the most important factors influencing biocatalytic reactions, various kinds of solvents were screened (Table 2 ). Generally, the BSA catalyzed domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction in protic or strongly polar solvents (e.g. ethanol, methanol, i-propanol, DMSO, DMF and MeCN) gave higher yields (70–85%) within relatively shorter reaction times (26–72h) (Table 2, entries 1–6) than reactions using aprotic and low-polar solvents (e.g. THF, chloroform, 1,4-dioxane) (Table 2, entries 7–9). The reaction in DMSO achieved a good yield of 76% within only 26h, while the reaction in ethanol gave an excellent yield of 85% in a much longer time of 72h (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). We attempted to study the cause of the above phonomenon. Interesingly, we dicovered that BSA could be well dispersed into the protic or strongly polar solvents such as in ethanol, DMSO, DMF and MeCN. The substrates 3-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one and malononitrile also dissolved well in the above solvents. However, BSA was not well dispersed in aprotic and low-polar solvents such as THF and chloroform. The solubility of the substrate 3-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one in chloroform was poor. The above investigation suggested that the dispersion of BSA and the solubility of the substrates may be the key factors influencing the reaction yield in different solvents. Better solubility probably means better contact between the catalyst and the substrate, which improves the yield. Based on the results of solvent screening and taking consideration to environmental protection, we choose ethanol as the optimum solvent for further investigation. As ratio of substrates is important to the result of a reaction, the effect of the substrates molar ratio was explored by fixing the amount of substrate 1a and changing the amount of substrate 2 in the model reaction (Table 3 ). When 1a was excessive (1a:2 =1:0.5), a poor yield of 21% was obtained (Table 3, entry 1). When 2 was excessive (1a:2 =1:3), the product could be obtained in a good yield of 85% (Table 3, entry 5). The results indicated that using excessive 2 is of benefit to improve the yield, but further increasing the molar ratio of 1a:2 to 1:9 did not lead to obvious improvement in yield (Table 3, entries 6–8). Obviously, the appropriate molar ratio of substrates is essential for improving the yield of a reaction. The reason that particular molar ratio is insufficient or sufficient was not clear. Based on the experiment results, the molar ratio of 1a:2 =1:3 was selected as the optimum ratio for further investigation. It is known that enzymes need essentially bound water in enzymatic reactions and the enzymatic activity in organic solvent depends on water content. Moreover, the water content required to reach the maximal activity is different in different organic solvents [39]. Just like most enzymes BSA is also a protein, and BSA has been found to have some unusual nonphysiological enzyme-like activities. Thus, the effect of water content on the BSA-catalyzed domino reaction was surveyed and the results were shown in Fig. 2 . The yield of 84% was obtained in absolute ethanol and the yield of 85% was obtained in ethanol containing 10% [v/v] of water. These yields were very similar. However, in consideration of that the use of more water instead of more ethanol would be more environmentally friendly, 10% water content was chosen as the optimum condition. Also, a sharp decline of product yields was exhibited with increasing water content more than 10% due to the poor solubility of the 3-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-1-phenylprop-2-en-1-one substrate in water. The reaction conditions were as follows: 1a (0.3mmol), 2 (0.9mmol), deionized water (0–1.0mL), ethanol (1.0–0mL) and BSA (30mg) at 25°C for 72h. Yield of the isolated product was after purification by silica gel chromatography. The reported yield in ethanol with 10% [v/v] water was the average of five experiments. The effect of BSA loading on the reaction was then examined (Fig. 3 ). The evident difference in the yield (50–85%) was observed for BSA loading ranging from 10 to 30mg, but no further improvement was detected when BSA loading was continuously increased from 30mg to 90mg. These results may be explained as follows. In the presence of enough substrates, initially increasing the amount of a catalyst in a reaction system could increase the reaction rate. In this BSA-catalyzed domino reaction, the catalyst BSA is not in solution; it is rather in suspension and acts as a heterogeneous catalyst. When BSA loading surpasses a certain amount in a reaction system, the degree of dispersion of the BSA declines which reduces the efficiency of catalysis. Based on the experiment results, BSA loading of 30mg was chosen as the optimal condition. The reaction conditions were as follows: 1a (0.3mmol), 2 (0.9mmol), deionized water (0.1mL), ethanol (0.9mL) and BSA (10–90mg) at 25°C for 72h. Yield of the isolated product was after purification by silica gel chromatography. The reported yield with 30mg BSA was the average of five experiments. Reaction temperature also plays an important role in organic synthesis, as it may affect the reaction rate and the stability of BSA. Hence, the effect of temperature on the BSA-catalyzed domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction was investigated (Table 4 ). It can be seen that the highest yield of 87% was obtained at 30°C after 72h (Table 4, entry 2). The yield decreased sharply with increasing temperature, and some complicated by-products were generated after long time reaction at high temperature. Then the reaction was performed at higher temperature for shorter time, but only low yields of 67% (at 70°C) and 59% (at refluxing temperature) were obtained (Table 4, entries 7 and 8), probably due to the partial denaturation of BSA at higher temperatures. Meanwhile, a blank experiment in refluxing ethanol without albumin was also conducted, and the product was obtained in a yield of 22% (Table 4, entry 9). Thus, 30°C was selected as the optimum reaction temperature. The time course of the reaction was also examined (Fig. 4 ). In the initial stage of the reaction, a rapid increase of product 3a was observed. After the first 24h, the rate of the increase of product 3a began to slow down. This could be explained as the follows. A rapid reaction rate was observed at the initial stage of reaction as there was a high concentration of substrates. As the reaction continued, substrates were consumed gradually and the concentration of substrate was low, which lead to a decrease of reaction rate. Anyhow the yield of the product 3a kept increasing before 72h. However, unexpectedly, after 72h, the yield of product 3a dropped evidently; prolonging the reaction time to 144h product 3a was only obtained with a yield of 52%. On this occasion, some complicated unknown by-products were observed. It indicated that under the reaction conditions some side-reactions can happen on product 3a, which consumed the product 3a leading to a low yield as prolonging the reaction time. From the above results, it can be seen that not only over increasing temperature, but also excessive extension of the reaction time could cause decreases of the yield. The reaction conditions were as follows: 1a (0.3mmol), 2 (0.9mmol), deionized water (0.1mL), ethanol (0.9mL) and BSA (30mg) at 30°C for specific times. Yield of the isolated product was after purification by silica gel chromatography. The reported yield at 72h was the average of two experiments. To investigate the generality and scope of the reaction, a variety of α,β-unsaturated ketones were tested to expand this novel BSA-catalyzed domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction (Table 5 ). Satisfactory results were achieved with 2-hydroxy-chalcones bearing various substituents. Generally, high yields were obtained for the reactions of malononitrile with 2-hydroxy-chalcones with an electron-withdrawing substituent on the aryl ring adjacent to the carbonyl group (R 2) (Table 5, entries 2–4, 7 and 8). On the contrary, the reactions using 2-hydroxy-chalcones with an electron-donating substituent on the same aryl ring (R 2) gave lower yields (Table 5, entries 9–12). When R 2 was furyl, the reaction still performed well, giving the product with a good yield of 81% (Table 5, entry 5). Also the 2-hydroxy-chalcones with different R 1 substituents reacted well with the malononitrile, except the nitro substituted chalcone 1m which gave a low yield of 47% (Table 5, entry 13), probably due to the low solubility of the substrate. The reaction with the dichloro-substituted chalcone only afforded the product in a yield of 50% (Table 5, entry 15) which may be attributed to steric effects. Unfortunately, there was no enantiomeric excess of the products observed by the chiral HPLC analysis. The products obtained were all racemic. Interestingly, when 2-hydroxybenzalacetones were used to react with malononitrile in this BSA catalyzed reaction, another type of products was obtained (Table 6 ). After the domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction, excess malononitrile adds to the carbonyl of the cyclization product, forming the products (5a–c) in yields of 26–34% (Table 6, entries 1–3). Increasing the amount of malononitrile did not lead to better yields, but instead some unknown complicated by-products were observed. 4 Conclusion In summary, BSA was found to be an environmentally benign biocatalyst for the domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reaction. Through this reaction, various 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives could be synthesized in yields of 31–96% starting from easily available 2-hydroxychalcones and malononitrile using ethanol as the reaction medium. A wide range of substrates could participate in the reaction. As an example of biocatalytic methods, this work not only broadens the use of BSA in chemical transformations, but also could be a potentially valuable tool in organic synthesis in view of the low cost and sustainability of this catalyst and the simplicity of this work. coredata.dc:description: A domino reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives using bovine serum albumin (BSA) as a catalyst in ethanol was described. The domino Michael addition/intramolecular cyclization reactions of readily available 2-hydroxychalcones with malononitrile gave the desired products in yields of 31–96% under the optimized conditions. As an example of biocatalytic methods, this work not only broadens the BSA-catalyzed chemical transformations, but also could be a potential valuable tool in organic synthesis in view of the economical and sustainable catalyst and simple operation.
coredata.dc:title: A domino reaction for the synthesis of 2-amino-4H-chromene derivatives using bovine serum albumin as a catalyst
